• The behavior of nonlinear systems, including the transition from regular to chaotic behavior, is sensitive to system parameters.

• Cataclysmic variables (CVs) are short-period binaries containing a white dwarf (WD) primary and a low-mass main sequence secondary, with the secondary filling its Roche lobe and transferring mass to the WD through the inner Lagrangian point.
• The main features of the orbital period distribution of CVs with hydrogen-rich donors are the lack of systems in the 2-3 hour period range (the so-called period gap) and the sharp cut-off of the distribution at around 77 minutes.
• Theoretical models have been unable to reproduce the precise position of the observed short-period cut-off and the observed shape of the CV orbital period distribution near this cut-off.
• Systems that evolve under the influence of gravitational radiation (GR) as the only sink of orbital angular momentum reach a minimum period at around 5.7 minutes, but the probability of finding a system within a given period range is proportional to the time taken to evolve through this region, leading to an accumulation of systems (a spike) at the minimum period.
• The orbital period evolution reflects the radius evolution of the mass donor, which is governed by two competing effects: mass transfer perturbs thermal equilibrium and expands the star, while thermal relaxation reestablishes thermal equilibrium and contracts the star back to its equilibrium radius.
• The position of the minimum period is affected by the assumed mass transfer rate and, in particular, by the assumed rate of orbital angular momentum (AM) losses. In this paper, the authors investigate ways to increase the period minimum by increasing the mass transfer rate and investigate ways to "hide" the spike by introducing a spread of minimum period values in the CV population.
• The authors study the effect of a form of consequential AM loss (CAML) where the AM is lost as a consequence of the mass transferred from the secondary, and present detailed calculations of the long-term evolution of CVs, comparing the observed short-period CV period distribution with various theoretically synthesized model distributions based on these calculations.

• **Normal Galaxies as XRB Contributors**: Normal galaxies are likely to be the most numerous extragalactic X-ray sources in the universe and are expected to dominate the number counts at 0.52 keV fluxes of 10^-15 erg cm^-2 s^-1.
• **CDF-N Depth**: The CDF-N has reached the depths necessary to detect individually many normal galaxies to z ~ 1.5, corresponding to a look-back time of ~ 8 Gyr.
• **Star Formation Rate**: One expects the X-ray luminosity per unit B-band luminosity to be larger at higher redshifts due to the increased energy output of X-ray binary populations.
• **X-ray Emission as Fossil Record**: This X-ray emission represents a fossil record of past epochs of star formation, allowing measurements of X-ray luminosities of typical galaxies to constrain models of X-ray binary production in galaxies.
• **Stacking Technique**: While X-ray emission from individual galaxies is not easily detected at faint flux levels, it is possible to estimate the emission at these levels using statistical methods such as stacking.
• **CDF-N Study**: The authors extend the study of normal galaxies to the entire CDF-N plus flanking fields region, focusing on galaxies at z ~ 0.5 to 1.0 to complement the study of z ~ 2-3 galaxies performed in a previous paper.

• **Observational Evidence for Accelerated Expansion**: The first observational evidence of the universe's accelerated expansion was obtained when supernovae type Ia were found to be fainter than expected. This fact has been confirmed by many independent observations such as temperature anisotropies of the cosmic microwave background, inhomogeneities in the matter distribution, the integrated Sachs-Wolfe effect, baryon acoustic oscillations, weak lensing, and gamma-ray bursts.

• **Dark Energy as the Driver**: Within the framework of general relativity, the accelerated expansion is driven by a new energy density component with negative pressure, termed dark energy. The nature of this unknown matter field has given rise to a great scientific effort to understand its properties. The observational evidence is consistent with a cosmological constant being the possible origin of the dark energy driving the present epoch of the accelerated expansion of our universe, and a dark matter component giving rise to galaxies and their large-scale structures.

• **Coincidence Problem and Interacting Models**: The nature of the unknown matter field has given rise to a great scientific effort to understand its properties. The value of the cosmological constant is many orders of magnitude smaller than what it was estimated in particle physics. It was suggested soon that dark energy could be dynamic, evolving with time. This new cosmological model suffers from a severe fine-tune problem known as the coincidence problem. Cosmological models where dark matter and dark energy do not evolve separately but interact with each other were first introduced to justify the currently small value of the cosmological constant and have been found to be very useful to alleviate the coincidence problem.

• **Future Observations and Constraints**: Current and future observations could and will be used to set up constraints on interactions between dark sectors and clarify the nature of dark matter/dark energy interactions. Observations of type Ia supernovae, baryon acoustic oscillations, gravitational lensing, redshift-space distortions, and the growth of cosmic structure probe the evolution of the universe at low redshifts. In parallel, the physics of dark matter/dark energy interactions at recombination can be probed by the cosmic microwave background radiation power spectrum, while the integrated Sachs-Wolfe effect and lensing pattern of the cosmic microwave background sky are sensitive to the growth of matter at lower redshifts.

• Time series classification is a crucial task in data mining, with 1-nearest neighbor (1-NN) using Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) distance being a top performer.
• Euclidean distance is commonly used but DTW distance often provides more accurate results for time series data.
• Sakoe-Chiba band (SC band) speeds up DTW calculation and serves as a global constraint, originally with a fixed width of 10% of the time series length.
• Recent work suggests that the optimal SC band width depends on the data properties, determined by testing all possible widths.
• Ratanamahatana-Keogh band (RK band) generalizes the global constraint model, allowing multi-band adjustments per class.
• The original RK band learning algorithm uses a hill-climbing search with accuracy and distance metrics, but can suffer from overfitting.
• This paper proposes two new learning algorithms: Band Boundary Extraction and Iterative Learning, using Silhouette Index as a heuristic function.
• The final 1-NN classification uses the discovered band and a lower bound (lb_Keogh) to speed up computation.

• The theoretical description of hadron production at large transverse momentum involves a two-step process: hard scattering of partons followed by fragmentation.
• Fragmentation is traditionally described using fragmentation functions, but this approach is inadequate for intermediate transverse momentum in heavy-ion collisions.
• Recombination of partons is a more appropriate hadronization process, especially for soft partons, and is the focus of this paper.
• The purpose of this paper is to introduce the notion of shower partons and determine their distributions to represent fragmentation functions in terms of recombination.
• The authors aim to quantify the properties of shower partons and illustrate their importance in recombination with thermal partons in heavy-ion collisions.

• **Publication Overload**: The vast amount of scientific publications makes it challenging to select high-quality works enriched with original ideas and relevant to the scientific community.
• **Citation Mechanism**: The citation mechanism is often used to discover such publications, with the number of citations serving as an estimate of scientific credibility.
• **Power-Law Distribution**: Empirical studies, such as those by Redner, show that the citation distribution of scientific publications follows a power-law form with an exponent of -3.
• **Preferential Attachment**: This power-law behavior is a consequence of a preferential attachment process, where highly cited papers are more likely to acquire further citations.
• **Model Development**: The authors develop a simple model considering two research areas and referencing within and across each other, applicable to both scientific citations and the web of human sexual contacts.
• **Model Analysis**: The model is analyzed using a rate equation approach, focusing on the time evolution of network 1 and applying results to network 2.
• **Power-Law Exponents**: The model predicts power-law exponents for intra- and cross-link distributions, which can be tuned by varying coupling parameters, and are applicable to various complex systems.

• **Threshold Nets**: Obtained by assigning weights to nodes and connecting those whose combined weights exceed a threshold.
• **Degree Distributions**: Can be produced of almost arbitrary degree distributions, including scale-free, by choosing the weight distribution and threshold judiciously.
• **Architectures**: Encompass a wide variety of important architectures, from star graphs to complete graphs.
• **Study**: Have been studied extensively in the graph-theoretical literature and recently by statistical and non-linear physicists.
• **Hagberg et al.**: Exploited the fact that threshold graphs can be elegantly encoded by a two-letter sequence.
• **Two-Letter Sequence Nets**: Consists of two types of nodes, with one type connecting to none of the existing nodes and the other connecting to all.
• **Modularity**: Threshold graphs have a modular structure, with subsequences of one type of node forming cliques.
• **Structural Properties**: Various structural properties, such as degree distribution, triangles, betweenness centrality, and the spectrum and eigenvectors of the graph Laplacian, can be computed easily.
• **Design**: It becomes possible to design threshold nets with a particular degree distribution, spectrum of eigenvalues, etc.
• **Diameter**: The diameter of threshold nets is 1 or 2, regardless of the number of nodes.
• **Three-Letter Sequence Nets**: Can be constructed from a sequence formed from three letters by deterministic rules of connectivity.
• **Diameter**: The diameter of three-letter sequence nets is 3 or 4, comparable to many everyday life complex nets.
• **Classification**: All possible forms of connected three-letter sequence nets have been derived, leading to 30 distinct equivalence classes.
• **Extension**: A natural extension of threshold nets to three-letter sequence nets has been identified.
• **Mapping**: Some three-letter sequence nets can be mapped into threshold nets with two thresholds.
• **Open Problems**: Numerous open questions remain, such as the possibility of further reducing the class of three-letter nets and finding mappings to generalized threshold nets.
• **Future Work**: The authors hope to tackle some of these questions in future work.

• **Gamma-Ray Bursts (GRBs)**: Powerful, short flashes of gamma-rays, lasting from less than a second to tens of seconds, observed above Earth's atmosphere with satellite-based detectors.
• **Origin and Distance**: Still unexplained, but known to be at cosmological distances with measured redshifts up to 4.5.
• **Energy Release**: Involves huge energy releases, up to 10^18 erg, assuming isotropic emission.
• **Possible Explanations**: The collapse of a very massive star (hypernova) and the coalescence of a compact binary system are the most likely candidates.
• **Gravitational Waves (GW)**: Expected to be associated with these events, with a predicted duration of a few milliseconds.
• **GW Detection**: Present resonant detectors can detect GW bursts, but a signal from a single GRB appears hopeless.
• **Correlation Study**: A program was launched to study the presence of correlations between GRB events and GW signals from detectors like Nautilus and Explorer.
• **Bayesian Analysis**: The study uses a Bayesian approach to infer the GW amplitude and energy, given the observed cross-correlation.
• **Results and Limitations**: The study provides upper limits on GW amplitudes and improves previous limits, but results depend on the choice of prior probability density function.

• **Discrete Differential Geometry for Fermionic Field Theory**: The text discusses the use of discrete differential geometry to describe the geometric meaning of continuum vector theories, with a focus on the Dirac-Kähler formulation of fermionic field theory.
• **Challenges in Discretization**: Defining a discrete differential geometry scheme that maintains the properties of the continuum and has the correct continuum limit has proven challenging, with difficulties often exhibited by the Hodge star and the wedge product between forms.
• **Proposed Scheme**: The authors propose a local, discrete differential geometry scheme for an arbitrary topological space, which has been thoroughly studied by de Beauc, Samik Sen, Siddartha Sen, and Czech. The scheme uses two parallel lattices to maintain the locality of the Hodge star and a finite element scheme to capture the properties of the wedge product.

• **Problem Definition**: The document discusses a nonconvex semidefinite programming problem involving matrix-valued mapping inequality constraints, with applications in static output feedback controller design and topology optimization. The problem is known to be nonconvex and NP-hard, and previous attempts to solve it have used convex semidefinite programming techniques.

• **Methodology**: The authors propose a new method based on convex-concave decomposition of bilinear matrix inequality (BMI) constraints and linearization techniques. The method exploits the convex substructure of the problems and can be applied to solve many problems in static output feedback control, including spectral abscissa, H-infinity, and mixed H2-H-infinity synthesis problems.

• **Contribution and Outline**: The contribution of the paper is threefold: (1) generalizing the inner convex approximation method from scalar optimization to nonlinear semidefinite programming, (2) proving the convergence of the algorithm to a stationary point under mild conditions, and (3) providing two particular ways to form an overestimate for bilinear matrix-valued mappings and showing their applications in static output feedback. The paper is organized into sections that recall definitions and notation, propose the main algorithm and investigate its convergence properties, show applications in static output feedback control and numerical tests, and conclude with some remarks.

• **High Temperature Superconductivity and Exotic Gap Symmetry**:
  - The advent of high temperature superconductivity in cuprates and the possibility of exotic gap symmetry, including nodal behavior, has led to renewed efforts to find novel experimental probes of order parameter symmetry.
  - One result of this effort was the proposal by Sauls and co-workers to examine the nonlinear current response of d-wave superconductors, which showed that a nonanalyticity in the current-velocity relation at temperature Tc is introduced by the presence of nodes in the order parameter.
  - Early experimental work did not verify these predictions, and it was suggested that impurity scattering or nonlocal effects may be responsible.
  - However, a more recent reanalysis of experiment has claimed to confirm the predictions, and an alternative proposal by Dahm and Scalapino examined the quadratic term in the magnetic response of the penetration depth, which shows a T^3 dependence at low T as first discussed by Xu et al.

• **Nonlinear Microwave Current Response as a Sensitive Probe**:
  - Dahm and Scalapino demonstrated that this upturn would provide a clear and unique signature of the nodes in the d-wave gap and that this feature could be measured directly via microwave intermodulation effects.
  - Experimental verification of this has been obtained, confirming that nonlinear microwave current response can be used as a sensitive probe of issues associated with the order parameter symmetry.
  - The goal of the current work is to compare in detail the differences between one-band and two-band s-wave superconductors in terms of their nonlinear response, as measured in the coefficients defined by Xu et al. and Dahm and Scalapino.

• **One-Band S-Wave Superconductor**:
  - The superfluid current has been considered theoretically in the past for s-wave and other order parameters, such as d-wave and f-wave.
  - Most recently, the case of two-band superconductivity has been examined with good agreement obtained between theory and experiment for the temperature dependence of the critical current.
  - In this work, the superfluid current as a function of superfluid velocity or momentum is calculated, and the nonlinear term is extracted from this.

• **Two-Band Superconductor**:
  - The generalization of the expression for the superfluid current to the two-band case is presented, and the temperature-dependent nonlinear term is extracted from the current.
  - The case of MgB2, which is already under scrutiny for possible applications including passive microwave filter technology, is considered as a specific example

• The source document discusses the observation and analysis of GRB 090510, a gamma-ray burst detected by multiple spacecraft.
• The burst was observed to have a precursor emission, a main emission, and a high-energy emission extending to the GeV range.
• The source was also associated with a high-energy GeV emission, which is a common feature of short GRBs.
• The GeV emission of GRB 090510 was particularly intense, reaching one of the largest observed values among short GRBs.
• The absence of GeV emission in short GRFs (short GRB flashes) is confirmed by the strong upper limit to the GeV emission imposed by the Fermi-LAT sensitivity.
• The source document also discusses the theoretical analysis of the broadband emission of GRB 090510 within the synchrotron/self-synchrotron Compton (SSC) and traditional afterglow models.

• The invariance of Maxwell's equations under the @xmath0 group was discovered a century ago, but quantizing the Maxwell field requires gauge fixing, typically using the Lorenz gauge, which breaks this invariance.
• The purpose of the paper is to demonstrate the benefits of maintaining @xmath0 invariance during the quantization of the Maxwell field in conformally flat spaces (CFS).
• A classical @xmath0-invariant field cannot distinguish between two CFS, so the authors suggest maintaining @xmath0 invariance during quantization.
• The work confirms this assertion in the special case of Maxwell's field in de Sitter space, where a new two-point Wightman function was found.
• The paper extends this work to general CFS and clarifies the quantum structure of the formalism.
• The authors use Dirac's six-cone formalism and realize all CFS as intersections of the null cone and a given surface in a six-dimensional Lorentzian space.
• Auxiliary fields and the Gupta-Bleuler quantization scheme are used to deal with the gauge freedom of the Maxwell field.
• A suitable coordinate system is used to give @xmath0-invariant CFS formulas a Minkowskian form.
• The main result is a set of Wightman two-point functions for Maxwell and auxiliary fields.

• The parallel chip-firing game is a periodic automaton on graphs where vertices, each containing non-negative chips, fire one chip to each neighbor if possible.
• The game's rules and notation are defined, including the step operator, complement position, and confined position.
• Lemmas are established to bound the number of chips on a vertex, define the complement position, and find a necessary and sufficient condition for a period to occur.
• The complete bipartite graph is considered, and possible periods are determined to be of length 2 or 3.
• A lemma is proven to bound the number of times a vertex has fired once the position is confined.
• A sufficient condition for a period of a position on the complete bipartite graph to occur is given.
• All possible periods for the complete bipartite graph are characterized.
• Positions on the complete 2-partite graph with period 1, 2, 3, and 4 are constructed.
• The main theorem states that a non-negative integer is a possible period of a position on the complete bipartite graph if and only if it satisfies certain conditions.
• Future research directions include bounding periods of positions on vertex-regular graphs, determining which periods less than the bound are possible, and studying the transient length of games on certain graphs.

• **Cognitive Radio Systems and Interference Management**: The efficient use of the scarce spectrum in wireless applications has led to significant interest in the analysis of cognitive radio systems. One scheme allows secondary users to transmit concurrently with primary users, as long as the interference power at primary receivers is kept below a predefined limit.
• **Wireless Communications Vulnerability**: The broadcast nature of wireless transmissions allows signals to be received by all users within the communication range, making wireless communications vulnerable to eavesdropping.
• **Information-Theoretic Security**: The problem of secure transmission in the presence of an eavesdropper was first studied by Wyner, who defined secrecy capacity as the maximum achievable rate from the transmitter to the legitimate receiver while keeping the eavesdropper ignorant of the transmitted messages.
• **Cognitive Radio and Information-Theoretic Security**: Although cognitive radio networks are susceptible to eavesdropping, the combination of cognitive radio channels and information-theoretic security has received little attention. Recent work has studied secure communication over multiple input, single output (MISO) cognitive radio channels.
• **Collaborative Relay Beamforming in Cognitive Radio Networks**: This paper investigates collaborative relay beamforming under secrecy constraints in cognitive radio networks. The authors characterize the secrecy rate of the amplify-and-forward (AF) cognitive relay channel and formulate the beamforming optimization as a quasiconvex optimization problem, which can be solved through convex semidefinite programming (SDP). They also propose two suboptimal null space beamforming schemes to reduce computational complexity.

* The study of nonequilibrium phase transitions is a growing field with applications to various complex systems, including the Ziff-Gulari-Barshad (ZGB) model for catalytic oxidation. The ZGB model exhibits two phase transitions between active and poisoned states, which have been studied using mean field theory and simulations.
* The authors investigate the effects of inert sites on the phase transitions of the ZGB model by incorporating a random distribution of inert sites on the catalytic surface. They perform mean-field (site and pair approximations) calculations and Monte Carlo simulations to determine the phase diagram, spinodal and transition lines, and hysteresis curves for different concentrations of inert sites. The study finds that the first-order transition changes to a continuous one at a critical concentration of inert sites.

• A choice of nonconstant meromorphic function on a compact Riemann surface realizes it as a finite sheeted branched covering of the Riemann sphere.
• Log-Riemann surfaces of finite type are certain branched coverings of the punctured compact Riemann surface by a meromorphic function.
• The map extends to the metric completion as a Lipschitz map, and the order of ramification points can be defined.
• A log-Riemann surface is of finite type if it has finitely many ramification points and finitely generated fundamental group.
• An exp-algebraic curve is an equivalence class of log-Riemann surface structures of finite type, given by a punctured compact Riemann surface and germs of meromorphic functions with poles at the punctures.
• A topological space can be associated to an exp-algebraic curve, with the set of infinite ramification points and the weakest topology such that all maps extend continuously.
• For a meromorphic function or 1-form with exponential singularities, a divisor can be defined.
• A degree zero line bundle with a meromorphic connection can be associated to an exp-algebraic curve.
• The correspondence gives a one-to-one correspondence between exp-algebraic structures on the Riemann surface and degree zero line bundles with meromorphic connections.

* Myles Hollander is a statistician who has made significant contributions to the field of nonparametric statistics.
* He has written three books on the subject, including a popular book called "The Statistical Exorcist" with Frank Proschan.
* Hollander has also served as the chair of his department at Florida State University for nine years.
* He is known for his sense of humor and his ability to make statistics accessible to a wide audience.

• The paper discusses the hydrodynamic limit for interacting particle systems in the crystal lattice.
• The crystal lattice is a generalization of classical lattice, with a free abelian group acting freely on it and a finite quotient graph.
• The paper extends problems of the hydrodynamic limit to the crystal lattice, which has periodic global structures but inhomogeneous local structures.
• The crystal lattice has been studied in view of discrete geometric analysis by Kotani and Sunada.
• They formulate a crystal lattice as an abelian covering graph and study random walks on crystal lattices.
• The standard realization is a discrete harmonic map from a crystal lattice into a euclidean space, characterizing an equilibrium configuration of crystals.
• The paper constructs the scaling limit of the crystal lattice using discrete harmonic maps.
• The scaling limit of the crystal lattice is a torus, equipped with the flat metric induced from the euclidean metric.
• The paper proves the convergence of the combinatorial laplacian on the crystal lattice to the laplacian on the torus.
• The paper formulates the symmetric simple exclusion process and the weakly asymmetric simple exclusion process on the crystal lattice and states the main theorem.

• The fundamental group of the complement of plane curves is a topological invariant used to distinguish connected components of the moduli space of smooth projective surfaces.
• The Zariski-Lefschetz hyperplane section theorem states that the fundamental groups of complements of curves can be used to compute the fundamental groups of complements of hypersurfaces in projective space.
• A pair of plane curves is called a Zariski pair if they have the same combinatorics but their complements in projective space are not homeomorphic.
• The fundamental group of the affine Ceva arrangement has no conjugation-free geometric presentation.
• The fundamental group of a real arrangement whose graph has a unique cycle of length 3 and has no line with more than two multiple points has a conjugation-free geometric presentation.
• The fundamental group of a real arrangement whose graph is a unique cycle of any length and has no line with more than two multiple points also has a conjugation-free geometric presentation.

• Organic molecular crystals are promising for nanoscale devices in electronics and optoelectronics.
• They consist of organic molecules held together by weak van der Waals forces.
• The electronic structure of the interface between organic and inorganic components is crucial for device performance.
• Charge transfer between the components and the energies involved need to be understood.
• Upon adsorption on a substrate, electron addition and removal energies change from their gas phase counterparts.
• This is due to polarization of the substrate and image charge formation.
• A quasiparticle (qp) description is commonly used to calculate these energies.
• However, density functional theory (DFT) has limitations in describing qp energies, especially for molecules.
• The formation of the image charge is a non-local phenomenon, challenging for local and semi-local functionals.
• Constrained density functional theory (CDFT) is a resource-efficient alternative to calculate charge transfer energies.

* The system studied consists of two spherical colloids immersed in a near-critical binary liquid mixture and close to a homogeneous, planar substrate. The colloids have different boundary conditions (BCs) and are positioned at varying distances from each other and the substrate.
* The total normal and lateral forces acting on one of the colloids (colloid 2) are characterized by universal scaling functions, which are studied as functions of the scaling variables ratio and .
* The many-body contribution to the critical Casimir forces (CCFs) is determined by subtracting the pairwise forces from the total force. The scaling functions associated with the normal many-body CCFs exhibit a change of sign at fixed temperature upon varying the lateral position of colloid 2, indicating a zero many-body contribution to the normal force at a specific lateral position.

• **Harmonic Maps**:
  - Introduced by Fuller, Nash, and Sampson, first general result by Eells and Sampson.
  - Critical points of energy functional between Riemannian or pseudo-Riemannian manifolds.
  - Trace of second fundamental form vanishes.

• **Energy and Tension Field**:
  - Energy density: smooth function defined for each tangent vector.
  - Tension field: section defined by the Laplacian of energy density.
  - Harmonic map: tension field vanishes identically.

• **Index and Stability**:
  - Index: dimension of tangent subspace where Hessian is negative definite.
  - Stable: Morse index is zero, unstable otherwise.

• **Horizontal and Vertical Spaces**:
  - Decomposition of space into vertical and horizontal spaces.
  - Horizontally conformal: restriction of second fundamental form to horizontal space is surjective and conformal.

• **Applications of Harmonic Maps**:
  - Used in computational fluid dynamics, minimal surface theory, string theory, gravity, and quantum field theory.

• **Pseudo-Riemannian Manifolds**:
  - Harmonic maps between pseudo-Riemannian manifolds require restricted classes.
  - This paper focuses on almost para-Hermitian and almost paracontact manifolds.

• **Almost Para-Hermitian Manifolds**:
  - Endowed with an almost para-complex structure and compatible pseudo-Riemannian metric.
  - Eigenbundles are totally isotropic with respect to the metric.

• **Para-Kähler Manifolds**:
  - Almost para-Hermitian manifold with a closed fundamental 2-form.
  - Equivalent to the metric being para-Hermitian.

• **Almost Paracontact Manifolds**:
  - Equipped with an almost paracontact structure and pseudo-Riemannian metric.
  - Normal almost paracontact manifolds: almost paracomplex structure is integrable.

<summary>
* **Multiple Optimised Parameter Estimation and Data Compression (MOPE-D)** is an algorithm for compressing data and speeding up likelihood function evaluations in astronomical data analysis.
* MOPE-D is particularly useful when the noise covariance matrix depends on model parameters, requiring calculation and inversion at each likelihood evaluation.
* However, MOPE-D only guarantees maintaining the Fisher matrix of the likelihood at a chosen point, which can lead to issues with multimodal and some degenerate distributions.
* The algorithm provides significant speed improvements when it accurately represents the likelihood function, but it may create erroneous peaks that hinder parameter estimation.
</summary>

* **Method**: Two-color modulation transfer spectroscopy is presented for studying atomic properties in excited states.
* **Key Features**: The method uses two lasers (pump and probe) and generates sidebands that act as an in-situ ruler for measuring energy separations or locking laser frequency to excited transitions.
* **Advantages**: It overcomes low signal-to-noise ratio and detector availability issues, and eliminates Doppler background.
* **Application**: The method is demonstrated on rubidium atoms, showing high precision measurements and agreement with theoretical calculations.

<summary>
* The SI second is defined by the resonance of cesium-133 atoms at a specific frequency, 9,192,631,770 Hz, at absolute zero temperature.
* Atomic clocks are passive and require an active oscillator to function.
* The resonance of the atom or atoms in the atomic clock varies with the details of its construction and operation, particularly the intensity of the radiation of the atoms by the oscillator.
* The SI second is defined by the resonance that would be found at absolute zero temperature, implying zero radiation.
* The wave function incorporated into the operation of an atomic clock can never be unconditionally known.
* The language of quantum theory reflects a distinction between 'explanation' and 'evidence', offering linear algebra of wave functions and operators for explanations and probabilities on a set of outcomes for evidence.
* Outcomes are subject to quantum uncertainty, and it is uncertain how to know that a wave function describes an experimental situation.
* The distinction within quantum theory between linear operators and probabilities implies a gap between any explanation and the evidence explained.
* The second as a unit of measurement in the SI is affected by the unknowability of wave functions, with implications for digital communications and the use of a spacetime with a metric tensor in explaining clock readings at transmission and reception of logical symbols.
</summary>

<summary>
* The star formation rate (SFR) of galaxies is a crucial measure for understanding the hierarchical build-up of the universe over cosmic time. Large-scale simulations have shown that unregulated star formation leads to an overabundance of high-mass galaxies, suggesting that some process must be able to stop or "quench" star formation before the galaxy grows too big. Supermassive black holes (SMBHs) are believed to play a role in this process by regulating the SFR through feedback mechanisms.
* The authors present a large sample of 313 Seyfert galaxies selected using ultra-hard X-ray observations with the Swift/Burst Alert Telescope (BAT) and imaged with Herschel/Spire. They focus on the overall luminosity distributions at the Spire wavebands and the Spire colors to determine the likely heating sources of cold dust in AGN host galaxies and to look for correlations with a proxy for the bolometric AGN luminosity.
* The study finds that Seyfert 2s are detected at a higher rate than Seyfert 1s, and after accounting for upper limits, Seyfert 2s have slightly higher Spire luminosities than Seyfert 1s. However, the effect is small, indicating that the global FIR properties of AGN are independent of orientation. The Spire luminosities are correlated with each other, suggesting that the process (or processes) producing the emission from 70-500 μm is connected. None of the Spire luminosities are well correlated with the 14195 keV luminosity, a proxy for the bolometric AGN luminosity.
* The study also finds anomalous colors for 6 BAT AGN, indicating that the FIR seds for these AGN are dominated by synchrotron emission from a radio jet rather than thermally heated dust. Another group of AGN with less anomalous colors but still removed from the main locus were analyzed by fitting the seds with a modified blackbody and calculating a 500 μm excess. The 500 μm excess is not related to radio loudness but is well correlated with the 14195 keV luminosity and the 3.4/4.6 μm color from WISE. The authors speculate that this is possibly related to the millimeter excess emission recently seen in AGN caused by coronal emission above the accretion disk.
</summary>

<summary>
* Molecular hydrogen (H2) is the most abundant molecule in the universe and plays a crucial role in the chemistry of the interstellar medium.
* Its formation is governed by the transformation of atomic diffuse clouds into molecular clouds, with dust grains being the favored habitat for H2 molecule formation.
* The sticking of hydrogen atoms (H) onto dust surfaces is an important mechanism for H2 formation, which can also cool interstellar gas.
* In the interstellar medium (ISM), dust grains are mainly carbonaceous or silicate particles, with a large part of the available surface area for chemistry being in the form of very small grains or polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs).
* PAHs are predicted to have characteristics similar to graphite surfaces, and once the first H atom is chemisorbed on the basal plane, subsequent adsorptions of H atoms in pairs appear to be barrierless for the para dimer and with a reduced barrier for the ortho dimer.
* H2 can then form by involving a pre-adsorbed H atom in monomer or in a para-dimer configuration, but the inefficient sticking of H atoms in monomers constitutes an important obstacle to enter the catalytic regime for H2 formation on graphitic/PAH surfaces.
* The hydrogenation on the PAH edges has been identified as an important route to form H2 in the ISM, and density functional theory calculations have shown that the first hydrogenation of neutral coronene is associated with a barrier but that subsequent hydrogenation barriers vanish.
* In this letter, the authors study experimentally the hydrogenation of coronene cations in the gas phase through exposure to hydrogen atoms using mass spectrometry, showing that odd hydrogenation states of coronene cations predominantly populate the mass spectrum.
</summary>

<summary>
* The cosmological constant problem (CCP) is a major puzzle in particle physics, consisting of several pieces:
	+ The vacuum energy density can be the cosmological constant and has various sources, such as zero-point energy of particles and phase transitions.
	+ The vacuum energy density can receive large radiative corrections, including a cutoff scale.
	+ The experimental value of the cosmological constant is much smaller than the theoretical estimate.
* The vacuum energy density is negative and has a pressure, contributing to the cosmological constant.
* The CCP is not fitted within the framework of Einstein gravity and the Standard Model of particle physics.
* The authors suggest that a dominant part of dark energy can originate from gravitational corrections of vacuum energy, assuming that classical gravitational fields do not couple to a large portion of the vacuum energy effectively.
* The evolution of dark energy is studied, and several possibilities for physics beyond the terascale are discussed, including no sensitive physics, miraculous cancellations, or the presence of another graviton.
</summary>

• Recent investigations have revealed complex relationships between galaxy properties and their environments using data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS).
• Galaxy clustering is a function of both star formation history and luminosity, with different dependencies for low and high luminosity galaxies.
• Color and luminosity appear to have a more fundamental relationship with environment than surface brightness and concentration.
• The scale dependence of these relationships has been explored, with some studies finding conflicting conclusions.
• The authors address the dependence on scale of the relative bias of SDSS galaxies in their study.

* The text discusses the zero-field hall effect in chiral @xmath0-wave superconductors (SCs) near the Kosterlitz-Thouless (KT) transition.
* The hall conductivity is nonzero due to vortex dynamics, even in the absence of a magnetic field.
* The main result is nonvanishing hall conductivity and ac conductivity near the KT transition.
* The hall conductivity shows strong positive peaks and sign changes in certain frequency and temperature ranges.
* The behavior of the hall conductivity is influenced by the dip-recouping shape of the transverse response function.
* The convective term in the Fokker-Planck equation, due to broken time-reversal symmetry, is essential to this asymmetry.
* The results depend solely on the convective ratio and are valid without an applied magnetic field.
* Temperature controls the pair size distribution, determining the sign of the hall conductivity.

• **IEEE 802.15.4 Standard**: Targeted for wireless body area networks (WBANs), requires low power and low data rate applications, supports 2.4 GHz band, star and peer-to-peer topologies, beacon-enabled and non-beacon-enabled modes.
• **MAC Protocols**: IEEE 802.15.4 supports contention-based (CSMA/CA) and schedule-based (TDMA) MAC protocols, with CSMA/CA used in non-beacon-enabled mode.
• **Performance Analysis**: The paper focuses on analyzing IEEE 802.15.4 with non-beacon-enabled mode in a star topology using CSMA/CA, considering varying data rates, load, throughput, delay, and end-to-end delay.
• **Simulation Parameters**: Simulations were performed using OPNET Modeler, considering 10 sensor nodes, coordinator, and data rates of 20, 40, and 250 kbps, with and without ACK.
• **Load**: Load remained constant at all data rates, with no significant difference between delay and end-to-end delay.
• **20 kbps**: Maximum delay of 2145 seconds and maximum throughput of 4352 bits/sec at 60 minutes were recorded.
• **40 kbps**: Maximum delay of 380 seconds and minimum delay of 2.5 seconds, with the highest throughput of 8805 bits/sec at 60 minutes.
• **250 kbps**: Delay was negligible, with throughput matching load at 10388 bits/sec.
• **Performance Analysis**: IEEE 802.15.4 performed best at 250 kbps, with less collision probability and minimum delay, and worse at 20 kbps with higher end-to-end delay.
• **ACK vs No ACK**: IEEE 802.15.4 performed better without ACK due to decreased collision probability, especially at higher data rates.

<summary>
* The physics potential of forward proton tagging at the LHC has attracted significant attention in recent years.
* A main focus of interest is the central exclusive production (CEP) process, in which the protons remain intact and the central system is separated from the outgoing protons by a large rapidity gap.
* Observation of any particle in the central exclusive channel would provide a direct observation of its quantum numbers.
* By detecting the outgoing protons and measuring their energy loss accurately, it is possible to measure the mass of the centrally produced particle regardless of its decay products.
* The FP420 collaboration has proposed to install detectors in the region 420 m from the interaction points, which would allow the detection of central systems in the approximate mass range 70-140 GeV.
* Proposals also exist to upgrade the capabilities of ATLAS and CMS to detect protons in the 220 m region, which would extend the accessible mass range well beyond 140 GeV.
* In this paper, the focus is on the central exclusive production of the Standard Model (SM) Higgs boson and a supersymmetric (MSSM) Higgs boson, with a mass of 120 GeV.
* The CEP process is shown schematically in Figure [centralexclusive].
</summary>

<summary>
* Transverse spin fluctuations are gapless, low-energy excitations in magnetic systems with continuous spin-rotational symmetry.
* They play a crucial role in various macroscopic properties, such as long-range order, order parameter magnitude, and spin correlations.
* In the antiferromagnetic ground state of the half-filled Hubbard model, transverse spin fluctuations significantly reduce the zero-temperature order parameter in two dimensions.
* The Néel temperature in three dimensions is also reduced due to these fluctuations.
* Recent interest has focused on spin fluctuations caused by defects, disorder, and vacancies in quantum antiferromagnets.
* A new method is described to evaluate transverse spin correlations and quantum spin-fluctuation corrections about the Hartree-Fock level.
* This method is applicable in the whole range of interaction strength and is illustrated with three applications involving the antiferromagnetic ground state of the half-filled Hubbard model.
* The method allows for the determination of the critical vacancy concentration at which the antiferromagnetic order parameter vanishes.
</summary>

<summary>
* The trihydrogen dication (H3+) is a simple Coulomb system consisting of three protons and one electron, whose stability has been extensively studied.
* Conroy's work in the 1960s and 1970s concluded that H3+ is not stable based on potential energy surface analysis using a variational approach.
* Later studies by Schwartz and Schaad, Somorjai and Yue, and others also found no evidence of stable H3+.
* Shoucri and Darling, and Hernandez and Carb revisited the issue using more advanced methods but still found no bound state.
* Johnson and Poshusta, and Ackermann et al. performed further calculations, with the latter using the finite element method and excluding the possibility of stable H3+ in the electronic ground state.
* The present study aims to address the question of H3+ existence again, motivated by the possibility of a metastable state in a magnetic field.
* The study explores the stability of H3+ using two methods: a specialized variational approach with physically relevant trial functions and a standard variational approach using Gaussian trial functions.
* The specialized approach leads to lower variational energy values with fewer terms, but relies on careful optimization of non-linear parameters. The study concludes that H3+ does not exist in an equilateral triangular configuration in the Born-Oppenheimer approximation.
</summary>

<summary>
* The measurement of rotation curves (RCs) of disk galaxies is a powerful tool to investigate the nature of dark matter (DM), including its content relative to baryonic components and their distributions. Dwarf galaxies are particularly useful for this purpose as their kinematics are generally dominated by the dark component, down to small galactocentric radii.
* The Orion dwarf galaxy is examined in this study due to its extended disk, providing an important test of the DM density profiles arising in cold dark matter (CDM) numerical simulations. Recent studies suggest that kinematic data of dwarf galaxies are better fitted by a DM halo with a constant density core than one that is centrally peaked.
* The Orion dwarf's kinematics unambiguously point towards a cored profile, making it critically important for investigating the nature of DM particles and the evolution of DM halos. The galaxy's high-quality, high-resolution RC can be easily corrected for asymmetric drift and tested for non-circular motions, showing a large mass discrepancy at all radii.
* The Orion dwarf is modeled as consisting of two luminous components (stellar and gaseous disks) embedded in a dark halo. The stellar component is modeled as an exponential thin disk, while the gas component's contribution to the observed RC is derived from the total intensity map. Two different parametrizations of the mass distribution are considered for the dark halo: an NFW profile and the cored profile of the Halo Universal Rotation Curve (URCH).
</summary>

<summary>
* The study of nonequilibrium dynamics in quantum field theory has received much attention in various areas of physics, particularly in cosmology, driven by the success of inflation as a mechanism for explaining the large-scale homogeneity and isotropy of the universe.
* The work has focused on understanding inflation and its dynamics, with observations now able to directly test the more detailed predictions of specific inflationary models.
* One area of particular interest is the dynamics of multi-field models of inflation, where the inflaton is coupled to another dynamical field during inflation, leading to a variety of features unavailable in single-field models.
* The subsequent phase of energy transfer between the inflaton and other degrees of freedom leading to the standard picture of big bang cosmology has also been a subject of intense study.
* The inflaton may decay through perturbative processes as well as non-perturbative parametric amplification, which can lead to explosive particle production and very efficient reheating of the universe.
</summary>

• The paper presents a new optomechanical system design consisting of a microdisk resonator coupled to a waveguide, enabling the study of reactive effects in optomechanical coupling.
• The origin of reactive coupling lies in the mechanical motion dependence of the extrinsic losses of the disk resonator and phase-dependent gradient forces.
• The system is more effective in achieving cooling to its ground state, desirable for studying quantum effects at the macroscopic scale.
• The paper reports reactive-coupling-induced normal mode splitting in the output fields, unlike previous works that only used dispersive coupling.
• The system's Hamiltonian, input-output relation, and time evolutions of expectation values are derived and solved, leading to the observation of normal mode splitting due to reactive coupling.

• **Quantum Communication**: New quantum mechanical technologies promise to fundamentally alter communication, with Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) enabling secure communication.
• **Quantum Network**: A new telecommunications infrastructure is required to accommodate quantum properties, including quantum memories, repeaters, and channels.
• **Quantum Throughput**: The ability of a device to preserve quantum correlations in bipartite systems is crucial for quantum communication tasks.
• **Device Testing**: A testing procedure should be experimentally practical, using a finite number of test states and limited measurements.
• **Optical Systems**: Full tomography is not practical for optical systems due to the dimension of the Hilbert space, so a quantitative picture is needed.
• **Entanglement Measure**: The negativity is used as an entanglement measure, as it can be defined for unnormalized states and permits a positive prefactor to be absorbed into the state.
• **Quantum Device Testing**: The protocol involves sending part of an entangled state through the channel and determining the amount of entanglement remaining, using homodyne detection to estimate the most significant subspace.

<summary>
* The existence of dark matter (dm) has been established, and its thermal relic abundance has been determined by the WMAP experiment.
* An attractive candidate for dark matter is the weakly interacting massive particle (wimp), which can be accommodated economically in models beyond the Standard Model (SM) by introducing an inert scalar field.
* The Higgs triplet model (htm) is a simple model for generating neutrino masses, but it does not contain a dark matter candidate by itself.
* In a class of models where tiny neutrino masses are generated by higher orders of perturbation, the dm candidate can be naturally contained.
* In the htm, majorana masses for neutrinos are generated via a yukawa interaction with a nonzero vacuum expectation value (vev) of an SU(2) triplet scalar field.
* The vev of the triplet field is described by a dimensionful parameter, which breaks lepton number conservation at the trilinear term.
* The mass of the triplet field is assumed to be much larger than the electroweak scale, but there is no reason why the dimensionful parameter should be tiny in the htm.
* In this paper, an extension of the htm is considered, in which the dimensionful parameter is generated at the one-loop level, and the dm candidate appears.
</summary>

The Kosterlitz-Thouless-Halperin-Nelson-Young (KTHNY) theory is the most widely accepted theory, describing two separate transitions: the loss of translational order and the decay of orientational order, mediated by the unbinding of dislocations.
* However, the KTHNY theory assumes a dilute, unstructured distribution of lattice defects, which contradicts observations of dislocation alignment and accumulation into small-angle domain walls. The nature of the melting transition has been investigated for various systems, with inconclusive results ranging from first-order to KTHNY-like transitions. The equilibration time of the systems plays a crucial role in observing the hexatic phase, which may be metastable and not the true equilibrium configuration.

• **Star Formation and Cluster Evolution**: Stars form in clusters from giant molecular clouds, with only a modest percentage of gas turned into stars initially. After stellar winds and supernovae, the remaining gas is expelled, leaving the cluster out of equilibrium.
• **Dynamical State of Young Clusters**: Young clusters are often not in virial equilibrium due to rapid gas expulsion, which can cause them to expand and lose mass. This can lead to incorrect mass estimates based on velocity dispersions.
• **Observational Evidence**: Observations of young clusters in nearby starburst galaxies, such as M82-F, NGC 1569-A, and NGC 1705-1, show excess light at large radii, suggesting they are not in dynamical equilibrium.
• **Simulations and Models**: Simulations of gas expulsion from young clusters reproduce the observed excess light at large radii. Models with a star formation efficiency between 40-50% best match the observations.
• **Infant Mortality**: Rapid gas expulsion can cause young clusters to dissolve, leading to an excess of young, short-lived clusters. This is known as infant mortality and can explain the observed population of young clusters.
• **Implications for Initial Mass Function**: Clusters that are not in virial equilibrium may have incorrect initial mass functions (IMFs) estimated from dynamical mass measurements. Rapid gas expulsion can also cause clusters to lose a significant amount of stellar mass.
• **Future Work**: Further observations and simulations are needed to constrain the star formation efficiency within young clusters and better understand their dynamical state and longevity.

• **Source Document Overview**: The document discusses a statistical approach for handling nonignorable dropouts in longitudinal dyadic data, focusing on a specific study on breast cancer patients and their spouses.
• **Motivation and Aim**: The study aims to understand the interdependence of individuals within dyads and how the attributes and behaviors of one dyad member impact the outcome of the other. The specific aim is to characterize depression experiences and examine dyadic interaction and interdependence regarding depression over time.
• **Study Design and Data Collection**: Female patients with metastatic breast cancer were approached, and those meeting eligibility criteria were asked to participate. Depression in patients and spouses was measured at three time points using the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CESD) questionnaires. However, a substantial number of dropouts occurred.
• **Missing Data Mechanism**: The missingness of CESD measurements is likely related to the current depression levels of the patients or spouses, indicating a nonignorable missing data mechanism.
• **Proposed Methodology**: The researchers propose a fully Bayesian approach based on a selection model to deal with longitudinal dyadic data with nonignorable dropouts. They model each subject's longitudinal measurement process using a transition model and account for within-dyad correlation by introducing dyad-specific random effects.
• **Simulation Studies**: Two simulation studies were conducted to evaluate the performance of the proposed method. The first study compared the proposed method with complete-case and available-case analyses, while the second study assessed the method's performance when the missing data mechanism is misspecified.
• **Application to Breast Cancer Data**: The proposed method was applied to the longitudinal dyadic data collected from the breast cancer study. The results suggest significant 'partner' effects for both patients and spouses, indicating high interdependence and influence on each other's depression status. The method also identified more 'partner' effects than methods that ignore missing data, providing extra insights for designing more efficient depression prevention programs.

* Quantum electrodynamics predicts that electric and magnetic fields have zero-point energy, even in the absence of electromagnetic sources.
* Casimir predicted in 1948 that two electrically neutral metallic parallel plates in vacuum should attract each other with a force inversely proportional to the fourth power of separation.
* Lifshitz, Dzyaloshinskii, and Pitaevskii generalized Casimir's theory to isotropic dielectrics, deriving an analytical formula for the force between two uncharged parallel plates with arbitrary dielectric functions.
* The force between two plates made out of the same material is always attractive, regardless of the intervening medium, but for slabs of different materials, the sign of the force depends on the dielectric properties of the medium.
* Parsegian and Weiss derived an equation for the non-retarded van der Waals interaction energy between two dielectrically anisotropic plates immersed in a third anisotropic material.
* An author of the present paper analyzed a similar problem and found an equation for the Helmholtz free energy of the electromagnetic field, including retardation effects.
* The torque between two parallel birefringent slabs causes them to spontaneously rotate towards the configuration in which their principal axes are aligned.
* The Casimir-Lifshitz force between isotropic dielectrics has been verified in several high-precision experiments, but the torque between anisotropic materials has not been experimentally demonstrated or numerically calculated.
* In this paper, the authors calculate the magnitude of the torque induced by quantum fluctuations for specific materials and discuss possible experimental validations of the effect.
</summary>

• **Debris Disk Systems**: These are intermediate stages of stellar system evolution, representing the transition between early star and planet formation and mature systems like our solar system.
• **Observed Infrared Luminosity**: Although most primordial material is lost, debris disks show high infrared luminosity due to collisions of small bodies, much higher than estimated for our solar system's asteroid and Kuiper belts.
• **Gas Phase Absorption**: Researchers have been looking for gas phase absorption in debris disks since the detection of dusty circumstellar material around main sequence stars via infrared excesses.
• **Edge-On Orientation**: Only a few edge-on debris disks have been found, like HD 32297, which allows for simultaneous measurement of both dust and gas components.
• **HD 32297 Observations**: High-resolution optical spectra of HD 32297 and nearby stars were obtained using the Coudé spectrometer on the 2.7 m Harlan J. Smith telescope at McDonald Observatory.
• **Absorption Components**: Two absorption components were detected toward HD 32297, while only one was detected toward its neighbors, indicating circumstellar material causing the extra component.
• **Interstellar Medium (ISM) Absorption**: The ISM absorption is similar among HD 32297 and its closest neighbors, likely due to absorption from the shell defining the boundary of the local bubble.
• **Temporal Variability**: Some indication of temporal variability was detected over several epochs of observations, suggesting circumstellar variability in HD 32297's gas disk.

* Most modeling and analysis techniques are tailored to study dynamic processes in static networks, but real-world networks are constantly evolving over time.

* The authors present a method to compute couplings of operators in conformal field theories (CFTs) by deforming the theory with a marginal or irrelevant operator.
* The method is applicable to CFTs at a fixed point with a coupling constant, such as the 4D super Yang-Mills (SYM) theory.
* The authors show that the couplings can be determined by the anomalous dimension matrix of the deformed theory.
* The method is valid to linear order in the deformation parameter and works for both marginal and irrelevant deformations.
* The authors provide an explicit formula for the couplings in terms of the anomalous dimension matrix.
* They also show that the couplings can be computed by diagonalizing the anomalous dimension matrix of the critical theory and finding the action of the deformation matrix on the basis of operators.
* The authors apply the method to the 4D SYM theory at weak coupling and show that it can be used to compute the couplings of operators to the lagrangian.
* They also discuss the possibility of extending the method to other deformations and to operators that are not exact.
* Finally, the authors mention that the method could be useful in unveiling new integrability structures in the perturbative computation of the couplings.

* The simplest candidate for dark energy is the cosmological constant, but it faces challenges such as the small observed value compared to quantum field theory predictions and the age problem in the Lambda-CDM paradigm.
* Alternative dark energy models, such as quintessence, phantom, k-essence, tachyon, quintom, chaplygin gas, generalized chaplygin gas, holographic dark energy, new agegraphic dark energy, and Ricci dark energy, have been proposed to address these issues.

• **Diffusive Acceleration at Shock Fronts**: This phenomenon is extensively studied, with recent reviews providing detailed discussions on its current status. While much is now well understood, some issues remain subjects of debate, particularly the backreaction of accelerated particles on the shock.
• **Backreaction of Accelerated Particles**: The violation of the test particle approximation occurs when the acceleration process becomes sufficiently efficient to generate pressures of the accelerated particles comparable to the incoming gas kinetic pressure. This changes both the spectrum of the particles and the structure of the shock, making it intrinsically nonlinear.
• **Approaches to Backreaction**: There are three main approaches to account for the backreaction of particles upon the shock: numerical simulations, a fluid approach treating cosmic rays as a relativistic second fluid, and an analytical approach that treats the pressure of accelerated particles as a small perturbation.
• **Nonlinear Effects on Maximum Energy**: Recent studies have investigated the effects of the nonlinear backreaction of accelerated particles on the maximum achievable energy, along with the effects of geometry. The need for a practical solution of the acceleration problem in the nonlinear regime has been recognized.
• **Analytical Solutions**: Some promising analytical solutions of the problem of nonlinear shock acceleration have appeared in the literature, avoiding many of the limitations of previous approaches. Numerical simulations have been instrumental in identifying the dramatic effects of the particles' backreaction.
• **Nonlinear Effects on Spectrum**: The most visible effects of the backreaction of the accelerated particles on the shock appear in the spectrum of the accelerated particles, which shows a peculiar flattening at the highest energies. Analytical approaches reproduce well the basic features arising from nonlinear effects in shock acceleration.
• **Future Work**: Further investigation, particularly a detailed comparison of analytical results with numerical simulations of shock acceleration, is required to unveil the physical meaning of the multiple solutions for modified shocks. Phenomenologically, studying the implications of nonlinear shock reacceleration on astrophysical environments where the effect is expected to play an important role, such as supernova remnants, would be valuable.

* The master equations satisfy the Markov approximation and can be put into the Lindblad form, where the Lindblad operators contain the effect of the environment upon the system.

* The merger of two neutron stars, two black holes, or a black hole and a neutron star are among the most important sources of gravitational waves (GW), due to the huge energy released in the process.
	+ The coalescence of double neutron stars (DNS) may radiate about 10^56 erg in the last seconds of their inspiral trajectory, at frequencies up to 1.4 - 1.6 kHz, covered by most ground-based laser interferometers.
	+ The rate at which these mergings occur in the local universe is another parameter characterizing if these mergings are potential interesting sources of GW. Previous investigations have estimated a detection rate of one event every 125 and 148 years by initial LIGO and Virgo respectively, and up to 6 detections per year in their advanced configurations.
* Besides the emission produced by the coalescence of the nearest DNS, the superposition of a large number of unresolved sources at high redshifts will produce a stochastic background of GW.
	+ Different astrophysical processes susceptible to generate a stochastic background have been investigated, including distorted black holes, bar mode emission from young neutron stars, supernovas or hypernovas, and tri-axial rotating neutron stars.
	+ Populations of compact binaries, such as cataclismic variables, are responsible for the existence of a galactic background of GW in the MHz domain, which could represent an important source of confusion noise for space detectors like LISA.
* In this work, using the DNS merging rate estimated in a precedent study, the gravitational wave background spectrum produced by these coalescences was estimated.
	+ Numerical simulations based on Monte Carlo methods were performed to determine the critical redshift beyond which the duty cycle condition required to have a continuous background is satisfied.
	+ The signal frequency is in the range 10 - 1500 Hz, covered by ground-based interferometers, and the paper discusses the detection possibility with laser beam interferometers.
	+ The main conclusions of the paper are summarized, emphasizing the importance of DNS coalescences as a source of GW and the potential for detecting their stochastic background with advanced interferometers.
</summary>

• **Cosmological Model**: The cosmological model, known as the Lambda-CDM model, suggests that ordinary matter (baryonic) makes up only 4% of the total mass-energy, while dark matter (non-baryonic) accounts for 23%, and dark energy (Lambda) makes up the remaining 73%.
• **Dark Matter**: Dark matter is believed to play a crucial role in the formation of large-scale structures in the universe, acting as a gravitational catalyst for ordinary matter. It is thought to be non-relativistic (cold) at the time of galaxy formation and is often referred to as CDM (cold dark matter).
• **Dark Energy**: Dark energy, represented by the cosmological constant Lambda, is thought to be responsible for the accelerating expansion of the universe. Its exact nature is still unknown, but it is believed to have a negative pressure, causing it to repel gravity.
• **Modified Newtonian Dynamics (MOND)**: MOND is a theoretical framework that modifies Newton's laws of motion in the limit of weak gravitational fields. It is an alternative explanation for the observed flat rotation curves of galaxies, which is typically attributed to dark matter.
• **Dark Matter vs. MOND**: The debate between dark matter and MOND is still ongoing. Some argue that dark matter is the more fundamental explanation, while others suggest that MOND provides a more elegant solution to the observed phenomena.

• Half-metallic ferromagnets with high Curie temperatures are ideal for spintronics applications.
• Experimental and theoretical efforts have been devoted to designing and searching for such materials.
• Cr-doped dilute magnetic semiconductors (DMS) and Cr-based alloys, particularly CrAs and CrSb in zinc blende (ZB) structure, have attracted attention.
• Akainaga et al. grew ZB thin films of CrAs on GaAs (001) substrates by molecular beam epitaxy, which showed ferromagnetic behavior at temperatures in excess of 400 K.
• Theoretical calculations by Akainaga et al. and others have verified the half-metallic character of CrAs.
• The high value of Curie temperature (Tc) has also been supported by some of these studies.
• Thin films of CrSb grown by solid-source molecular beam epitaxy on GaAs, (Al, Ga)Sb, and GaSb have been found to be of ZB structure and ferromagnetic with Tc higher than 400 K.
• Galanakis and Mavropoulos examined the possibility of half-metallic behavior in ordered ZB compounds of transition metals V, Cr, and Mn with the pnictogens N, P, As, Sb, and Bi, and the chalcogens S, Se, and Te.
• Their theoretical study shows that the half-metallic ferromagnetic character of these compounds is preserved over a wide range of lattice parameters.

<summary>
* **Cosmic Rays**: Elementary particles arriving from outside Earth, discovered in the early 20th century, with a power law energy spectrum decreasing as the cube of the primary energy.
* **High Energy Cosmic Rays**: Particles with energies above a few hundred TeV, detected through extensive air showers, with an isotropic distribution and a possible change in spectral slope and composition above 10^20 eV.
* **Sources and Acceleration**: Few known astrophysical objects can accelerate particles to the highest observed energies, with no clear evidence for anisotropy, and no observed Greisen-Zatsepin-Kuzmin (GZK) cutoff.
* **Composition Studies**: Inclined showers can contribute to composition studies, with a recent analysis of inclined data in the Haverah Park array revealing two new events above 10^20 eV and placing a bound on the photon composition at ultra-high energies.
</summary>

<summary>
* Polymers with contour length much larger than persistence length are flexible and described by quantum mechanics and quantum field theory.
* As chain length decreases, chain stiffness becomes important and cannot be modeled by flexible polymer models.
* The Kratky-Porod model is a standard coarse-graining model for wormlike polymers, with essential ingredients being bending energy penalty and local inextensibility.
* Recent studies have shown increasing interest in theoretical description of semiflexible polymers due to potential applications in biology and semicrystalline polymers.
* The transverse distribution function of a 2D polymer embedded in 2D space possesses a bimodal shape for short polymers, indicating semiflexibility.
* This paper studies the transverse distribution function of a 3D wormlike chain with a fixed orientation of one polymer end using an exact representation.
* The exact solution of the Green's function made it possible to compute quantities such as the structure factor and end-to-end distribution function.
* Practically exact calculations demonstrate that the transverse distribution function of the 3D wormlike chain possesses a bimodal shape in the intermediate range of chain lengths.
* Analytical results for short and long wormlike chains are presented, agreeing with previous results obtained in different ways.
* The paper is organized into sections introducing formalism and analytical considerations, numerical computations, and discussion of results.
</summary>

• The NCSM/RGM approach, combining microscopic cluster techniques and realistic interactions, was extended to describe three-body cluster states.
• This extension enables the study of nuclear systems with three-body cluster structures, such as two-nucleon halo nuclei and transfer reactions.

• Preliminary results showed low-energy phase shifts for various channels in the continuum, including known and recently measured resonances.
• Future work will include core excitations using the No-Core Shell Model with Continuum (NCSMC) approach.

• The source document discusses the core entropy of polynomials, introduced by William Thurston, which measures the growth rate of the number of closed paths in a graph associated with the polynomial. The document presents an algorithm to compute the core entropy for rational angles and proves the continuity of the core entropy function.
• The document also introduces labeled wedges, which are combinatorial objects that capture the essential dynamics of the polynomial, and shows that the growth rate of the graph associated with a labeled wedge coincides with the core entropy for rational angles. The document then proves that the core entropy function extends to a continuous function from the set of all angles to the set of real numbers.

• **Cold Atoms in Optical Lattices**: A combination of quantum gases from atomic physics and laser theory from quantum optics, using artificial crystals of light to trap and study atoms.
• **Optical Lattices**: Created by interfering laser beams, forming periodic intensity patterns that can be 1D, 2D, or 3D, depending on the number of laser beams used.
• **Atoms in Optical Lattices**: Can be cooled and trapped in these lattices, mimicking the behavior of crystals in solid-state physics, with applications like studying Bloch oscillations, Wannier-Stark ladders, and tunneling phenomena.
• **Superfluid to Mott Insulator Transition**: A significant phenomenon in condensed matter physics, achieved in optical lattices using ultracold atoms, enabling the study of various condensed matter phenomena.
• **Bose-Einstein Condensation (BEC)**: The basis for the superfluid to Mott insulator transition, first predicted by Einstein in 1924, and observed experimentally in 1995 using rubidium atoms.
• **BEC and Ultracold Atoms**: Led to the observation of the superfluid to Mott insulator transition, opening up the possibility of using ultracold atoms in optical lattices as a test laboratory for condensed matter physics.
• **Double-Well Potential**: A simple experimental setup in optical lattices to study spin hamiltonians, created by superposing two standing waves with different periods and depths.
• **Hubbard Model**: A single-band lattice model supporting a single atomic state, used to describe the behavior of atoms in a double-well potential, with applications in studying spin ordering and magnetic properties.
• **Spin Ordering in Double-Well Potential**: Can be studied using the Hubbard model, with the potential bias controlling the energy difference between singlet and triplet states, and inter-well interactions playing a crucial role.
• **Inter-Site Interactions**: Important for studying spin ordering in cold atoms in optical lattices, with candidates including inter-site Coulombic interaction and exchange interaction, enabling the study of ferromagnetism and other magnetic properties.

• **Binary System & Planets**: The cataclysmic variable (CV) system Hu Aqr consists of a 0.80 white dwarf accreting from a 0.18 main-sequence companion star. It is orbited by two planets: a 5.7 Earth-mass planet in a 0.04 AU orbit with an eccentricity of 0.26, and a more massive (7.6 Earth-mass) planet in a wider (0.12 AU) and more eccentric (0.42) orbit.
• **Planetary Configuration & Stability**: The two-planet configuration was found to be dynamically unstable on a 100,000-year timescale, but a small fraction of numerical simulations exhibited long-term stability. The presence of planets orbiting a binary, especially a CV, is peculiar but could be common due to recent findings in other CVs.
• **Common-Envelope Phase & Planetary Migration**: After the birth of the binary, the primary star evolved until it overflowed its Roche lobe, initiating a common-envelope phase. The inner planet allows for breaking the degeneracy between the donor mass at Roche-lobe overflow, its radius, and the mass of its core, enabling the calculation of mass loss in the common-envelope phase. The outer planet validates this calculation and determines the conditions under which the CV was born.
• **Evolutionary History & Future Work**: The survival of planets around Hu Aqr offers unique diagnostics to constrain the origin and evolution of the system. The presence of one planet allows for calculating the rate of common-envelope loss, while two planets enable a precision reconstruction of the CV's evolution. Future work involves applying this method to other CVs and improving the understanding of common-envelope evolution.
